Business and First Class passengers typically have higher allowances, often up to 14 kilograms across two pieces. The cabin bag dimensions must not exceed 55cm x 38cm x 20cm to fit in overhead compartments or under the seat in front of you. In addition to your main cabin bag, Emirates allows one personal item such as a laptop bag, handbag, or small backpack, which generally isn't weighed separately if it's reasonably sized. However, it's crucial to verify your specific allowance on your Emirates ticket booking or by calling Emirates customer service, as allowances can differ for special fare types, codeshare flights, or if you've purchased extra baggage options. Check-in staff at the airport will weigh cabin bags if they appear oversized, and excess weight can result in being required to check the bag with applicable fees. To be safe, pack a lightweight cabin bag and keep heavier items in checked luggage.

question: My bag is 2 inches bigger than the size limit, is that okay?
answer: Airlines at Islamabad International Airport may show some flexibility for cabin baggage that's slightly oversized by an inch or two, but this is entirely at the discretion of the check-in staff and gate agents, and there's no guarantee your bag will be accepted. The official size restrictions exist because overhead compartments and under-seat spaces in aircraft have fixed dimensions, and bags exceeding these measurements genuinely cannot fit safely. If your bag is only marginally larger - especially if it's a soft-sided bag that can compress when placed in the sizing frame - you may be allowed to proceed, particularly if the flight isn't fully booked and overhead bin space is available. However, during busy flights or with strict airline policies, even slightly oversized bags will be required to be checked at the gate or counter, often incurring additional fees. Hard-shell cases have no flexibility, so if they exceed dimensions, they must be checked. To avoid last-minute stress, if you know your bag is borderline, consider checking it voluntarily at the counter rather than risking gate-checking, as voluntary check-in is often free while gate-checking might have fees.

question: Can I pack homemade mango pickle in my checked luggage?
answer: Yes, you can pack homemade mango pickle (achaar) and other traditional Pakistani pickles in your checked luggage, as these are food items allowed in checked baggage both for domestic and international flights from Pakistan. Homemade pickles are a popular item for travelers to carry between cities or take abroad as gifts or personal supplies. To pack pickles safely, use plastic containers or jars rather than glass, as glass can break during baggage handling, creating a mess and potentially damaging other bags. Make sure containers are completely sealed and leak-proof - double-bag them in plastic bags as an extra precaution, because pickle oil can seep through weak seals and stain clothing and other items in your suitcase. If you must use glass jars, wrap them very carefully in bubble wrap, towels, or clothing for cushioning, and place them in the center of your bag surrounded by soft items. For international travel, check your destination country's customs regulations regarding bringing in food products, as some countries restrict agricultural imports including pickles, oils, and preserved foods. Generally, small quantities for personal consumption are acceptable, but commercial quantities may face restrictions or require declaration.

question: I use a wheelchair, does it count in my baggage allowance?
answer: No, wheelchairs, mobility scooters, walkers, crutches, canes, and other mobility aids do not count toward your baggage allowance at Islamabad International Airport or on any airline operating from Pakistan. These assistive devices are transported completely free of charge regardless of size or weight, as they're classified as essential medical equipment under international aviation regulations. When you arrive at the airport, inform the check-in staff about your wheelchair so they can make appropriate arrangements - you can use your personal wheelchair throughout the terminal until reaching the aircraft door, where it will be tagged and stored in the aircraft hold. The airline will return your wheelchair to you at the aircraft door upon arrival, or you can request to have it delivered to the baggage claim area. If your wheelchair is battery-powered, special procedures apply depending on battery type - inform the airline in advance as lithium batteries require specific handling and documentation. Airlines provide manual wheelchairs free of charge if you need assistance moving through the airport. Besides wheelchairs, prosthetic limbs, portable oxygen concentrators (with prior approval), and other medical devices also travel free and don't affect your baggage allowance.

question: My wife is inside, can I check in her baggage from here?
answer: No, the passenger whose name is on the ticket must be physically present at the check-in counter with valid identification and boarding pass to check in baggage. This is a strict security regulation at all Pakistani airports including Islamabad International Airport, enforced to prevent unauthorized persons from checking bags and to ensure that the person responsible for the baggage contents is identified. Family members can certainly assist with carrying or pushing luggage to the counter, but the actual ticket holder must appear in person, present their ID (CNIC for domestic, passport for international), and confirm they packed their own bags when asked security questions by check-in staff. This rule exists because the passenger is legally and personally responsible for everything in their checked baggage, and staff need to verify identity and ask mandatory security questions directly to the traveler. If your wife is elsewhere in the airport, she needs to come to the check-in counter to complete the process. Airlines cannot accept baggage from anyone other than the ticketed passenger, even immediate family members, due to aviation security regulations.

question: I'm carrying my cricket kit, do I need any special documents?
answer: No special documents or permits are required to carry cricket equipment as checked baggage at Islamabad International Airport - you only need your regular boarding pass and identification. Cricket bats, pads, helmets, gloves, stumps, and other cricket gear are commonly transported by passengers, especially on domestic Pakistani routes where the sport is extremely popular, and airlines are very familiar with handling such equipment. Your cricket kit will count toward your regular checked baggage weight allowance, so if your gear is heavy and you're concerned about exceeding limits, you might want to distribute items between multiple bags or be prepared to pay excess baggage fees. Cricket bats must be in checked luggage and cannot be carried in cabin baggage due to their potential use as a weapon - security will stop you if you attempt to bring them through the security checkpoint in hand luggage. For international travel, cricket equipment typically doesn't face import restrictions at most destinations, though it's wise to check if you're traveling to countries unfamiliar with the sport. If you're carrying valuable signed bats or specialized equipment, consider getting additional insurance coverage as airline liability for checked baggage is limited.

question: Can I check in my mother's sewing machine as baggage?
answer: Yes, you can check in a sewing machine as baggage at Islamabad International Airport, as household items and appliances are generally permitted in checked luggage provided they're properly packed and fall within size and weight restrictions. Sewing machines, whether traditional foot-pedal models or modern electric ones, are common items transported by passengers moving between cities, sending to relatives, or taking abroad. Before packing, remove the power cord if it's an electric model and pack it separately or wrap it securely around the machine, ensuring no loose parts can move around during transit. Remove or secure the needle, as loose needles can cause injury to baggage handlers. Pack the machine in its original box if available, or use a sturdy cardboard box or hard-shell suitcase with plenty of cushioning material like bubble wrap, foam, or thick clothing to prevent damage from impact during handling. The machine will count toward your checked baggage weight allowance - sewing machines can be heavy, so verify your weight limit and be prepared for excess fees if you exceed it. If the sewing machine is particularly valuable or antique, take photos before packing as documentation for insurance purposes, though airline liability for checked items is limited.

question: My flight boards in 40 minutes, can I still check baggage?
answer: You are cutting it extremely close to the baggage check-in deadline, and whether you can check baggage depends on your flight type and airline. For domestic flights within Pakistan, baggage check-in typically closes 45 minutes before departure, while international flights close 60 minutes before departure. With only 40 minutes until boarding time, you're likely past the deadline for international flights and right at the limit for domestic flights. Rush immediately to the check-in counter and explain your situation - some airlines may make exceptions if the queue isn't long and your documentation is ready, but they're not obligated to accept late baggage as it risks missing the flight's baggage loading deadline. If check-in has officially closed, you'll be offered the option to fly with cabin baggage only if your bags meet size limits, or you may need to rebook on a later flight. To avoid this situation, airports recommend arriving 3 hours early for international flights and 2 hours for domestic flights. The check-in deadline exists because checked bags must go through security screening, be transported to the aircraft, loaded in the cargo hold, and all documentation processed - this sequence requires time that can't be compressed.

question: I want to take honey back to my village, any restrictions?
answer: Honey is classified as a liquid substance for aviation security purposes, so it must follow liquid restrictions depending on whether you're carrying it in checked or cabin baggage. For checked luggage, you can pack honey in any quantity without restrictions - it's perfectly acceptable to carry multiple jars or bottles in your checked bag. However, make sure containers are tightly sealed and leak-proof, and wrap them in plastic bags as a precaution, because honey can make a very sticky mess if containers crack or leak during handling. For cabin baggage, honey follows the 100ml liquid rule - you can only carry containers of 100ml or less, and they must be placed in a clear, resealable plastic bag along with other liquids like shampoo and lotion, with the total not exceeding 1 liter. Most passengers prefer to pack honey in checked baggage to avoid these restrictions and because honey bottles are often larger than 100ml. If you're traveling domestically within Pakistan, these rules apply but enforcement may be more relaxed. For international travel, be aware that some countries have agricultural import restrictions on honey due to disease concerns, so check your destination's customs regulations.

question: Can my telescope go in the overhead bin?
answer: Whether your telescope can go in the overhead bin as cabin baggage depends primarily on its size - it must fit within the standard cabin baggage dimensions of approximately 56cm x 45cm x 25cm (these exact measurements vary slightly by airline). Small portable telescopes, particularly refracting telescopes in compact carrying cases, often meet these requirements and can be carried in the cabin, which is actually preferable for expensive or delicate optical equipment. However, larger reflecting telescopes, dobsonian mounted scopes, or telescopes with extended tube lengths will exceed cabin size limits and must be checked as cargo. If your telescope is cabin-size but valuable, carry it on board to prevent potential damage from checked baggage handling - optical instruments are fragile and can be misaligned by impacts. Consider using a well-padded carrying case designed for telescopes, preferably a hard case for maximum protection. If you must check a larger telescope, pack it extremely carefully with foam padding, mark it as fragile, and consider purchasing additional insurance as airline liability for damaged items is limited. Remove or secure any loose parts like eyepieces, finder scopes, and mounting hardware separately.

question: My bag weighs exactly 23 kilos, will they still accept it?
answer: Yes, if your bag weighs exactly 23 kilograms, it will be accepted without any excess baggage charges, as 23kg is the standard checked baggage weight limit for economy class on most airlines. The weighing scales at check-in counters are calibrated and accurate, and you're fortunate to be precisely at the limit. However, be aware that even exceeding the limit by 0.5kg or 1kg can result in excess baggage fees, which vary by airline but typically start around PKR 500-800 per kilogram for domestic flights and USD 15-30 per kilogram for international flights. If during weighing your bag shows 23.2kg or similar minimal excess, you might politely request the check-in agent's discretion, though they're not obligated to waive charges. To avoid excess fees if you're borderline, wear your heaviest items like boots or jacket rather than packing them, or shift some items to your cabin baggage if there's space available within its 7kg limit. Each airline's policy differs - some strictly enforce weight limits while others show flexibility for minor overages, particularly for premium class passengers or frequent flyers. Always pack with a margin below the limit to account for scale variations.

question: Can I bring Karachi's famous sohan halwa for my relatives?
answer: Yes, you can absolutely bring traditional Pakistani sweets like Karachi's famous sohan halwa, Multani sohan halwa, Hafiz's sweets, or any other local mithai in both your checked baggage and cabin baggage. Traditional sweets are among the most commonly transported items by Pakistani travelers visiting family or friends in other cities or abroad, and airports are very familiar with passengers carrying these food gifts. Sohan halwa and similar dry sweets are not considered liquids, so they don't face the liquid restrictions that apply to items like syrup-based sweets. For checked baggage, pack sweets in their original boxes or secure containers to prevent crushing - place them between clothing or in rigid boxes for protection. For cabin baggage, sweets are allowed but keep them accessible as security might want to visually inspect the packaging to confirm contents. The main concern is packaging - avoid anything that could leak or become messy, and if carrying items with syrup or moisture, seal them in plastic bags. For international travel, packaged commercial sweets from recognized sweet shops are generally preferred over homemade items, as they appear more legitimate to customs officials. Most countries allow small quantities of packaged sweets for personal consumption without issues.

question: My PIA flight was canceled yesterday, can I reuse the baggage tags?
answer: No, you cannot reuse baggage tags from a canceled flight - all baggage tags become invalid when a flight is canceled or rescheduled, and you must obtain new tags for your rebooked flight. Each baggage tag contains specific barcoded information tied to a particular flight number, date, destination routing, and departure time, all of which have changed with your new flight. When you arrive at the airport for your rescheduled flight, proceed to the PIA check-in counter with your baggage, new booking confirmation, and identification. The check-in staff will issue fresh baggage tags with updated flight information and routing codes. Keep your old canceled flight documentation including the old baggage tag receipts in case of any disputes about rebooking or refunds, but these old tags are now just records, not valid for travel. The retagging process is quick - the staff will print new tags, attach them to your luggage, and give you new baggage claim receipts that you must safeguard until you collect your bags at your destination. This retagging requirement exists to prevent bags from being loaded onto wrong flights or misrouted through the baggage handling system.

question: Where can I buy bubble wrap to protect my items?
answer: Unfortunately, Islamabad International Airport doesn't sell packing materials like bubble wrap, foam, or padding supplies in the terminal area. However, you have several alternatives to protect fragile items. The most convenient option is the professional baggage wrapping service located near the check-in counters in the departure hall, which charges PKR 200-300 per bag to wrap your entire suitcase in industrial-strength plastic wrap - while this doesn't provide internal padding, it does secure and protect the exterior. For internal cushioning, if you have time before arriving at the airport, purchase bubble wrap, foam sheets, or packing paper from stationery shops, hardware stores, or packaging material suppliers in Rawalpindi or Islamabad city. Common shops like Pace, Metro, or local markets in Saddar have these supplies. As an improvised solution at the airport, you can purchase clothing items from airport shops and use them as padding around fragile items - thick socks, sweaters, or towels work reasonably well. Some travelers use newspapers, though these aren't available for purchase at the airport. The airport's duty-free shops and retail stores focus on travel essentials, gifts, and food rather than packing supplies.

question: Can I keep my electric shaver in my cabin bag?
answer: Yes, electric shavers, beard trimmers, and other battery-operated or rechargeable grooming devices are completely allowed in cabin baggage at Islamabad International Airport without any restrictions. These personal care electronic items are not classified as dangerous or prohibited goods. Keep your shaver easily accessible in your cabin bag because when you reach the security screening point, you may be asked to remove larger electronics for separate X-ray screening, though small grooming devices typically don't require removal. Both corded electric shavers and battery-operated models are permitted - if your shaver has a lithium battery, it's actually required to be in cabin baggage rather than checked luggage, as loose lithium batteries are restricted in checked bags due to fire risk. If your shaver has replaceable batteries, make sure the battery compartment is properly secured so batteries don't fall out during your journey. Other grooming tools like hair dryers, electric toothbrushes, and hair clippers are similarly allowed in cabin baggage. For liquid grooming products like shaving cream or aftershave, remember these must follow the 100ml liquid restriction and be in a clear plastic bag if carried in cabin baggage.

question: I work for PIA, what's my staff baggage allowance?
answer: As a PIA employee traveling on staff tickets or ID travel, your baggage allowance differs from regular passenger allowances and depends on several factors including your employment category, rank, route, and travel class. Generally, PIA staff have more generous allowances than regular passengers, but the exact weight and piece limits vary. For accurate information specific to your situation, you should check with the PIA employee services department, consult your company travel policy handbook, or contact the ID travel desk before your trip. When checking in for your staff travel, present your PIA employee ID card along with your staff ticket to the check-in counter, and they will apply the appropriate staff baggage allowance to your booking. The allowance typically varies between domestic and international sectors, with international flights often having higher limits. Some staff positions and seniority levels may have additional privileges. If you're traveling on a positive space confirmed ticket as opposed to standby, your allowances might differ. Never assume your allowance without verification, as showing up with excess baggage expecting automatic waiver can cause issues and potential charges.

question: I'm taking gold jewelry for my sister's wedding, any restrictions?
answer: You can transport gold jewelry and other valuable ornaments for personal or family use such as wedding gifts, but there are important security and customs considerations to keep in mind. For maximum security, always carry expensive jewelry in your cabin baggage rather than checked luggage - this keeps valuable items with you at all times and reduces theft risk. Checked baggage occasionally gets lost, delayed, or tampered with, and airline liability for valuable items in checked bags is very limited. While there's no restriction on the quantity of gold jewelry you can carry domestically within Pakistan, large quantities or high values should be documented with purchase receipts or family ownership records in case questions arise. For international travel, customs regulations become important - if you're carrying jewelry worth more than the duty-free allowance of your destination country, you may need to declare it and potentially pay import duty. Some countries have specific forms for temporarily importing jewelry that you'll take back with you. At Pakistani airports, security may ask to inspect jewelry during X-ray screening to verify it's genuine jewelry and not concealing prohibited items. Keep jewelry in original boxes or soft pouches to prevent damage and tangling.

question: My bag smells like biryani from the food I packed, is that a problem?
answer: A mild food odor from sealed food items like biryani in your checked baggage is generally acceptable and won't prevent your bag from being checked in, as many Pakistani travelers transport home-cooked food between cities or to relatives abroad. However, there are practical considerations to keep in mind. Strong, pungent smells that might permeate throughout the baggage hold and affect other passengers' luggage should be avoided out of courtesy. The main concern isn't the smell itself but rather whether the food is properly sealed and won't leak or spill during transit - biryani with gravy can be messy if containers aren't absolutely leakproof. Use rigid, sealed plastic containers rather than thin plastic bags or aluminum foil, and double-wrap them in plastic bags as a precaution. Place food containers in the center of your bag surrounded by clothing to absorb any potential leaks and minimize odor transfer. For cabin baggage, avoid bringing strong-smelling foods as the confined aircraft cabin space makes odors more noticeable and can disturb other passengers. Security personnel might inspect food items to ensure they're indeed food and not concealing prohibited materials. If the smell is extremely strong, check-in staff might suggest additional packaging or plastic wrap to contain the odor.

question: Can I take my tabla in the cabin instead of checking it?
answer: Yes, you can carry your tabla (traditional drum) as cabin baggage if it fits within the standard cabin baggage size dimensions of approximately 56cm x 45cm x 25cm and doesn't exceed the 7kg weight limit. Tablas, being relatively compact musical instruments, often fit these requirements especially if carried in a properly fitted soft case or bag. Musical instruments are valuable and can be damaged by rough handling in checked baggage, so carrying them in the cabin is actually the preferred option for many musicians. When you arrive at the check-in counter, inform the staff that you're carrying a musical instrument in cabin baggage - they may measure it to confirm it meets size requirements. Once on board, you can place the tabla in the overhead bin or under the seat in front of you, just like regular cabin baggage. If your tabla set is larger than cabin allowance or you have both tabla and other items exceeding combined limits, you'll need to check it. In that case, pack it very carefully with substantial padding, use a hard case if possible, mark it as fragile, and request delicate handling labels from check-in staff. Some airlines allow purchasing an extra seat for musical instruments that are too large for cabin but too valuable to check - inquire if this option interests you.

question: I bought perfume at duty-free, does it count as hand luggage?
answer: No, items purchased at airport duty-free shops after passing through security, including perfumes, alcohol, cosmetics, and other products, do not count toward your regular cabin baggage allowance. These duty-free purchases come in special sealed tamper-evident bags with the receipt visible inside, and you can carry these additionally along with your standard cabin baggage and personal item. This exception exists because you purchased these items after security screening in the sterile area of the airport, so they've already cleared security protocols. The duty-free bags can contain liquids exceeding the normal 100ml limit that would otherwise be prohibited in cabin baggage if brought from outside the airport. You can carry multiple duty-free shopping bags without worry. However, if you have a connecting flight, especially an international connection through another country, be aware that you might need to go through security again, and those destination airports might not accept your duty-free liquids if you're transferring. For final destination flights, keep your duty-free purchases in their original sealed bags with receipt visible until you reach your destination. Don't open or tamper with the sealed bags during the flight, as this could cause issues with customs or connecting security screenings.

question: My flight is at 5 AM, can I check baggage the night before?
answer: No, Islamabad International Airport does not offer night-before or overnight baggage check-in services. All baggage must be checked in on the same day as your flight departure, regardless of how early the flight is scheduled. For your 5 AM flight, check-in counters typically open 3 hours before departure for international flights and 2 hours before for domestic flights, which means counters open around 2 AM for your international flight or 3 AM for domestic. Yes, this requires arriving at the airport very early in the morning, but this is standard procedure for early morning flights worldwide. The requirement for same-day check-in exists because checked baggage must be continuously monitored for security, and airports cannot store bags overnight due to security protocols and liability concerns. Plan your transportation accordingly - you may need to arrange a taxi, use ride-sharing apps, or have family drive you to reach the airport by 2-3 AM. Some hotels near the airport offer early morning airport shuttle services. If you're traveling from far away, consider staying at an airport hotel the night before your early flight. Once you check in, you can rest in the departure lounge until your flight boards, as the terminal is open 24 hours.

question: My 5-year-old has a small school bag, does it count separately?
answer: Children who are 2 years old or above traveling on a purchased ticket (not as an infant on lap) are entitled to their own baggage allowance according to the ticket class they're traveling in, just like adult passengers. So your 5-year-old has their own separate checked baggage allowance (typically 20-23kg for economy class) and cabin baggage allowance (typically 7kg). Their small school bag would count as their personal item or cabin baggage within their allowance. In practice, airlines at Islamabad International Airport are generally flexible about small children's personal items - a small school backpack worn by a 5-year-old is unlikely to be weighed separately or strictly enforced, especially if it just contains toys, snacks, and entertainment for the flight. However, technically, if you're already at your cabin baggage limit with your own bags, the child's school bag is their cabin baggage and should be within the 7kg limit. Many families strategically pack heavier items in children's checked baggage since kids rarely pack 20kg of belongings, leaving capacity to split family items across multiple baggage allowances. If the school bag is truly tiny - just containing a toy and snacks - most airlines won't count it strictly. But if it's a full-size backpack, it counts as cabin baggage under the child's allowance.

question: I'm diabetic, can I carry insulin injections in hand luggage?
answer: Yes, passengers with diabetes can carry insulin, syringes, insulin pens, blood glucose monitors, test strips, lancets, and all other diabetic supplies in cabin baggage without quantity restrictions at Islamabad International Airport and all Pakistani airports. These are classified as essential medical supplies, and airports make accommodations for passengers who need medications during travel. Insulin actually should be carried in cabin baggage rather than checked luggage because the cargo hold's temperature fluctuations can potentially damage insulin's effectiveness. Carry your diabetic supplies in a clear case or bag for easy identification during security screening. While a prescription or doctor's letter is not legally required for insulin in Pakistan, having this documentation is highly recommended as it quickly verifies your medical need if questioned by security or customs officers. A doctor's letter should state your diagnosis, the prescribed insulin type and dosage, and that you require these supplies for medical purposes. Keep insulin in its original pharmacy packaging with labels showing your name and medication details. For international travel, carry enough insulin for your entire trip plus extra days' supply in case of delays, and research your destination's regulations about importing medications. Some countries require declaring medical supplies at customs.

question: How much can I declare for valuable items in my baggage?
answer: The standard liability limit that airlines have for checked baggage under international aviation rules (Montreal Convention) is approximately 1,131 Special Drawing Rights (SDRs), which equals roughly USD 1,500-1,700, or about PKR 400,000-450,000 at current exchange rates. This represents the maximum compensation you can receive if your checked baggage is lost, damaged, or delayed, regardless of the actual value of contents. Importantly, this limit applies per passenger, not per bag, and it's a maximum - compensation is based on actual documented losses up to this limit. The liability for domestic flights within Pakistan may be lower and is governed by Pakistan's domestic aviation regulations. If you're carrying items worth more than this liability limit - such as expensive jewelry, electronics, cameras, antiques, or other valuables - the airline is not responsible for the excess value unless you purchase additional insurance. You have several options: purchase excess valuation insurance directly from the airline at check-in (expensive but possible), buy travel insurance from independent providers that covers baggage loss up to higher amounts, or simply don't check valuable items and carry them in cabin baggage where you maintain physical control. High-value items should really travel in cabin baggage whenever possible rather than checked luggage.

question: Can I pack document photocopies in checked luggage?
answer: Yes, you can pack photocopies of documents in checked luggage, and in fact it's a good practice to keep backup copies of important documents separate from originals in case of loss or theft. However, never pack original important documents in checked baggage - always keep originals of your passport, national ID card, flight tickets, boarding passes, travel insurance documents, hotel reservations, medical prescriptions, credit cards, and any other critical papers in your cabin baggage where you have direct control and access. Checked bags occasionally get lost, delayed, or stolen, and if your original documents are inside, you'll face serious problems at your destination. The photocopies in checked luggage serve as backups - if something happens to your cabin bag or you lose documents during travel, you have copies that can help with police reports, embassy assistance for replacing passports, or proving identity. Consider also keeping digital scans of all important documents in your email or cloud storage (Google Drive, Dropbox) accessible from your phone - this provides another backup layer. Organize documents in a waterproof document holder or ziplock bag to protect them from potential moisture or spills in your luggage. Some travelers also leave copies of important documents with family members at home who can scan and email them if needed urgently.

question: My hiking backpack has a metal frame, will security stop me?
answer: Your hiking backpack with a metal frame will pass through security screening at Islamabad International Airport without issues, as metal frames in backpacks are common and not prohibited items. The X-ray machines and metal detectors are sophisticated enough to distinguish between structural metal components like frames and prohibited items like weapons. However, you should expect the screening process to take slightly longer because the metal frame will show up prominently on the X-ray screen, and security officers will want to ensure it's just a backpack frame and not concealing anything suspicious. When you place your backpack on the conveyor belt for X-ray screening, remove it from any protective covers, open all compartments and pockets, and remove any large items like laptops or tablets that need separate screening. The backpack itself can remain assembled with the frame inside. Security personnel may ask you to open the backpack for manual inspection, especially if it's heavily packed and the X-ray image isn't completely clear. Be cooperative and patient - this is routine procedure for bags with metal components. If you have trekking poles, tent stakes, or other hiking equipment with metal parts, these might require additional inspection. Carabiners, camping equipment, and similar metal outdoor gear are allowed in checked baggage but must be in checked luggage, not cabin baggage.

question: Can I bring clay pottery from Multan in checked baggage?
answer: Yes, you can transport clay pottery, ceramic items, and traditional Multani blue pottery in checked baggage, but extreme care must be taken with packing because these items are very fragile and easily broken during baggage handling. Pakistani handicrafts like Multani pottery, tile work, and ceramic pieces are commonly transported by travelers as gifts or personal items. Each pottery piece should be individually wrapped in multiple layers of bubble wrap, foam, or thick paper. If you don't have professional packing materials, use clothing, towels, or blankets to wrap each item separately. Place wrapped items in the center of your suitcase surrounded by soft items like clothes, never near the edges or corners where impacts are most severe. Fill all empty spaces in the bag with soft materials to prevent items from shifting during transit. Hard-shell suitcases provide better protection than soft bags for fragile items. If transporting multiple pottery pieces, pack them so they don't touch each other directly. Consider buying luggage wrapping service at the airport (PKR 200-300) for extra protection. Critically important: understand that airlines explicitly state they are not liable for damage to fragile items in checked baggage - you pack and check such items at your own risk. If pottery items are very valuable or irreplaceable, consider shipping them separately through a specialized courier service that insures fragile items.

question: It rained and my bag got wet on the way, will they accept it?
answer: Yes, slightly wet baggage from rain is acceptable for check-in at Islamabad International Airport, as airport staff understand that weather conditions sometimes cause luggage to get damp during transport to the airport. However, it's in your best interest to address the moisture before checking in. If the exterior is just damp, wipe it down with a towel or cloth available at the airport or from your car. If it's very wet, consider using the baggage wrapping service near check-in counters (PKR 200-300), which will seal the wet exterior and prevent moisture from affecting other passengers' bags in the cargo hold or dripping on airport floors. The most critical concern is protecting the contents inside your bag - immediately check that water hasn't seeped into the interior, especially around zippers and seams. Electronics, documents, and clothing inside must stay dry. If water has penetrated inside, try to dry the contents or transfer items to a plastic bag or dry bag to prevent further water damage during the flight. Water damage to baggage contents is typically not covered by airline liability if the exterior moisture was pre-existing and not caused by airline handling. For future trips during monsoon season, consider using waterproof luggage covers, rain bags, or wrapping your luggage in plastic before leaving home. Most modern suitcases have some water resistance, but prolonged rain exposure can lead to seepage.

question: I want to take my cricket bat and stumps to Lahore, is that allowed?
answer: Yes, cricket equipment including bats, stumps, pads, helmets, gloves, and protective gear can be transported in checked baggage on flights from Islamabad to Lahore or any other domestic route, and this is very common given Pakistan's passion for cricket. Your cricket equipment will count toward your regular checked baggage weight allowance (typically 20-23kg for economy class), so if you have a full cricket kit bag with bat, pads, helmet, gloves, and stumps, it can be quite heavy - ensure you're within your limit or be prepared to pay excess baggage charges. Cricket bats are considered potential weapons and cannot be carried in cabin baggage under any circumstances - they must be checked in. Pack your bat carefully with padding around it to prevent the blade from being damaged, and ensure it's secured so it doesn't shift and damage other items or the bag itself. Modern English willow bats are expensive and can crack if dropped, so consider a hard case if the bat is valuable. Stumps with sharp ends should be wrapped or covered so they don't tear through the bag or injure baggage handlers. For international flights, cricket equipment is generally not restricted, though very large items like practice nets or bowling machines might require special cargo arrangements. If you're a serious player traveling for tournaments, many team managers check full kit bags as group baggage.

question: Can I leave my bags here if I'm coming back through ISB in 3 days?
answer: No, Islamabad International Airport does not offer multi-day or long-term baggage storage facilities for passengers who are traveling onward and returning later. The left luggage service available at the airport is designed only for same-day or overnight storage during flight delays, layovers, or short visits, not for storage spanning multiple days between separate trips. For storing luggage for 3 days or longer, you'll need to use commercial storage facilities in Rawalpindi or Islamabad city. Some options include self-storage companies that offer secure locker services, certain hotels that provide luggage storage for guests (even after checkout, for a fee), or private luggage storage businesses near popular tourist areas. If you're staying at a hotel before your departure or after your return, ask if they can store your bags for a few days - many hotels offer this service to their guests for a minimal fee or sometimes free. The reason airports don't provide extended storage is due to security protocols - bags cannot be left unattended for multiple days due to security concerns, and airports lack the infrastructure to manage long-term storage with proper tracking and liability. For future planning, if you need to leave items between trips, arrange advance booking with a city storage facility, which is more secure and reliable than airport options anyway.

question: I'm taking an electric iron to my hostel, can I check it?
answer: Yes, electric irons and other household electrical appliances are completely allowed in checked baggage at Islamabad International Airport. Students and professionals frequently transport small appliances like irons, kettles, immersion heaters, and fans when moving to hostels, universities, or new accommodation. Before packing your electric iron in checked luggage, ensure it has completely cooled down if it was recently used - hot appliances can damage other items in your bag or pose a safety risk. Empty any water from steam iron reservoirs, as water can leak during baggage handling and damage clothing or electronics in your bag. If the iron has a detachable power cord, pack it separately or wrap it securely around the iron to prevent tangling with other items. Remove any batteries if your iron has battery backup, as loose lithium batteries are restricted in checked baggage - though corded irons typically don't have batteries. Pack the iron in the center of your suitcase surrounded by clothing or soft items for cushioning, as irons can be heavy and might damage other items if they shift during transit. The iron will count toward your checked baggage weight allowance, and irons can be several kilograms, so account for this weight. For international travel, verify your destination's voltage standards - Pakistan uses 220V, and your iron should be compatible with your destination's electrical system.

question: My company bag has logo stickers all over, is that acceptable?
answer: Yes, luggage with company logos, brand stickers, and decorative labels is completely acceptable and actually quite common at Islamabad International Airport. Many passengers use stickers to personalize their bags, making them easily identifiable on the baggage carousel and reducing the chance of another passenger accidentally taking your bag since many suitcases look similar. Company-branded bags from corporations, promotional bags from events, or luggage covered in travel stickers are all standard sights at airports. The only restriction would be if stickers or logos contain offensive content, hate symbols, or inappropriate imagery - these would violate airport conduct standards and might prompt staff to ask you to remove or cover them. Otherwise, corporate logos, sports team emblems, university badges, travel destination stickers, and brand names are all fine. In fact, travel experts recommend making your bag distinctive through stickers, colored ribbons, or unique tags because it speeds up identification at baggage claim and deters theft since a highly recognizable bag is harder to steal unnoticed. If your company bag is particularly distinctive with unique colors or design, you're less likely to experience the common problem of bag mix-ups where passengers accidentally take similar-looking bags. Just ensure stickers are firmly attached and won't peel off and potentially jam baggage handling equipment.

question: Can I pack climbing rope and carabiners in my checked bag?
answer: Yes, mountain climbing and rock climbing equipment including ropes, carabiners, harnesses, belay devices, ascenders, descenders, and climbing shoes are all permitted in checked baggage at Pakistani airports. Pakistan has a strong mountaineering community with many climbers heading to northern areas like Gilgit-Baltistan, Hunza, and K2 base camp, so climbing gear is commonly transported. Your equipment counts toward your regular checked baggage weight allowance, and climbing gear can be quite heavy especially with ropes, so watch your weight limits to avoid excess charges. Pack metal equipment like carabiners carefully so they don't damage the bag interior or other contents - consider a dedicated climbing gear bag or duffel. Coil ropes neatly and secure them to prevent tangling and make the bag easier to handle. Climbing harnesses and soft gear can go anywhere in the bag. Remove any sharp items like ice axes, crampons, or pitons from checked bags and pack them very carefully wrapped and secured, as truly sharp items may require additional security clearance. For international mountaineering expeditions, your equipment faces no restrictions, though commercial quantities of gear might raise questions. If you're part of a climbing expedition, coordinate with your team about distributing group equipment across multiple bags to avoid overweight issues. Consider gear insurance as airline liability for sports equipment is limited.
